wikipedia_page.main: Julius Beer (1836–1880) was a German-born English businessman, banker and newspaper baron. He owned The Observer from 1870 to 1880.

response: * Julius Beer (and family members), owner of The Observer.

In 1870, wealthy businessman Julius Beer bought the paper and appointed Edward Dicey as editor, whose efforts succeeded in reviving circulation. Though Beer's son Frederick became the owner upon Julius's death in 1880, he had little interest in the newspaper and was content to leave Dicey as editor until 1889. Henry Duff Traill took over the editorship after Dicey's departure, only to be replaced in 1891 by Frederick's wife, Rachel Beer, of the Sassoon family. Though circulation declined during her tenure, she remained as editor for thirteen years, combining it in 1893 with the editorship of The Sunday Times, a newspaper that she had also bought.

Armstead was living at 44 St Paul's Road, Camden in 1865. He Lived at 57 Camden Square from 1871 to 1883. He died at his home 52 Circus Road, St John's Wood in north London on 4 December 1905 and is buried in a family grave on the west side of Highgate Cemetery. Nearby in the west Cemetery is one of his works, in the Julius Beer Mausoleum - a sculpture of Ada Beer, Julius's young daughter, in the arms of an angel.
*Rachel Sassoon (later Beer), editor, (1858–1927; married Frederick Arthur Beer, son of Julius Beer).

In 1887, she married the wealthy financier Frederick Arthur Beer, son of Julius Beer (1836–1880), and converted to Christianity. Frederick, an Anglican Christian, was also from a family of converts. In the wake of her conversion, the family disowned her.The life and death of Rachel Beer, a woman who broke with convention

Obviously that's only suitable when a person is buried (rather than placed in a mausoleum, put on display in the Kremlin, etc.), but it gives an option to those that think the label "Resting place" is an unnecessary euphemism for someone who is actually buried. It works at Julius Beer. Shall I update  to reflect the change in the sandbox? --RexxS (talk) 18:56, 31 October 2015 (UTC)

Circa 1820, a new owner, the Comte de Turtot Hocquart, finding the château old fashioned, had it remodelled. In 1857, the estate was sold again, and purchased by Charles Tavernier, who built the lodge and redesigned and landscaped the grounds. In 1874, Tavernier gave the chateau to the banker Julius Beer, who gave it to  his son William. William's wife Elena created a notable literary salon there.Topic Topos  retrieved 31 October 2015. It was at the chateau that Leconte de Lisle wrote his work La Rose de Louveciennes.Topic Topos  retrieved 31 October 2015. The poet died while staying at the chateau's classical garden pavilion in 1894.
Julius Beer (November 28, 1843 – January 12, 1927) was a member of the Wisconsin State Assembly.
In 1865, Krausnick co-founded the Society for the History of Berlin together with Julius Beer and Ferdinand Meyer.
